title: Divinity of Christ
intro: Hypothesis: Jesus Christ, the Messiah, is God.

evidence.head: Claims to Divinity
evidence.short: Jesus seems to have claimed divinity. This is a hypothesis in its own right.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that Jesus actually did claim to be God.

Critics argue that Jesus may simply have made divine-sounding claims that were misunderstood by the early Church.

evidence.head: And the Word Was God
evidence.short: John opens his gospel account with a theological reflection on the Word of God: The Word was with God, and the Word was God.
evidence.details:
Proponents take this to mean that Jesus is the Word who became flesh and dwelt among us, and so Jesus is God.

Critics generally see this as some sort of non-literal affirmation. Some see it as an affirmation that Jesus is *a god* in a limited sense, but not *God* in the absolute sense. They often invoke John 10:34, where Jesus quotes Psalm 82:6, to point out that "god" is used more broadly.

bible.text: 1In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. 2The same was in the beginning with God. 3All things were made through him. Without him, nothing was made that has been made.
34Jesus answered them, “Isn’t it written in your law, ‘I said, you are gods’?

evidence.head: Jesus Walked on Water
evidence.short: Jesus walked on water and invited St. Peter to join him.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that Job says only God walks on the waves (in the Septuagint, "as on dry land"), and so this is good evidence in favour of a claim to divinity. Also, crossing the sea to show one's divinity was also an idea recognized in the Greco-Roman world, which is why the emperor Caligula rode a chariot across a bridge he had instructed to be built, so he could claim divinity while he was alive. Also, there is a likely allusion to Job 9:11 (and/or Exodus 33:22, 1 Kings 19:11) in Mark 6:48.

Critics argue that water miracles were done by Moses (Exodus 14:21–22) and Elisha (2 Kings 2:14) as well, and they were mere prophets acting with God's permission.

evidence.head: Jesus as a Prophet and Disciple of John the Baptist
evidence.short: Jesus acted like a prophet and was baptized by St. John the Baptist, another prophet, and seems to sort of "take over" for him after his death, much like Elisha after Elijah.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that St. John speaks of someone coming after him who is greater than him, and Jesus similarly speaks of those believing in him doing even greater works than he did. Also, just like St. John giving his disciples the ability to baptize for repentance, Jesus gave *his* disciples the ability to do what he does, e.g. forgive sins, heal people, see the future, and walk on water (Matthew 14:29–31). This seems to suggest a human line of prophets, similar to Elijah passing the torch to Elisha.

Proponents don't necessarily disagree with this, because Jesus was also fully man: He was Mary's son, and he grew in wisdom (Luke 2:52), so it is possible that he was, in *some* sense, a disciple of St. John the Baptist. However, Jesus and St. John were also baptizing people seperately and at the same time, so it doesn't look like Jesus was under his authority, at least not in the way St. John's other disciples were. And even if he were, this would not take away from his divine nature, because divine or not, Jesus was also a human prophet.

bible.summary: 2 Kings 2:8–15 (Elijah is taken up to Heaven, and Elisha carries on his prophetic legacy.)
bible.text: 8Elijah took his mantle, and rolled it up, and struck the waters; and they were divided here and there, so that they both went over on dry ground. 9When they had gone over, Elijah said to Elisha, “Ask what I shall do for you, before I am taken from you.” Elisha said, “Please let a double portion of your spirit be on me.” 10He said, “You have asked a hard thing. If you see me when I am taken from you, it will be so for you; but if not, it will not be so.” 11As they continued on and talked, behold, a chariot of fire and horses of fire separated them; and Elijah went up by a whirlwind into heaven. 12Elisha saw it, and he cried, “My father, my father, the chariots of Israel and its horsemen!” He saw him no more. Then he took hold of his own clothes and tore them in two pieces. 13He also took up Elijah’s mantle that fell from him, and went back and stood by the bank of the Jordan. 14He took Elijah’s mantle that fell from him, and struck the waters, and said, “Where is YHWH, the God of Elijah?” When he also had struck the waters, they were divided apart, and Elisha went over. 15When the sons of the prophets who were at Jericho facing him saw him, they said, “The spirit of Elijah rests on Elisha.” They came to meet him, and bowed themselves to the ground before him.

evidence.head: Matthew's Changes
evidence.short: The line where the scribes think only God can forgive sins is missing in Matthew, and the crowd says God has given such authority to man, even though his gospel almost always overlaps with Mark's.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that if Mark's account is earlier, Matthew's removal of this part could indicate that an understanding had developed that it wasn't the case that only God could forgive sins, and that Jesus was not God, but rather a man with authority *from* God.

Proponents argue that God has given the authority to man, but that Jesus is not *merely* a man, although the crowd would not know this. Why Matthew left out the part about forgiving sins, he could have had any number of reasons for it (e.g. copying error), and Matthew doesn't always copy Mark verbatim, even though he includes almost all of the same episodes, though often shortened.

bible.text: 1He entered into a boat and crossed over, and came into his own city. 2Behold, they brought to him a man who was paralyzed, lying on a bed. Jesus, seeing their faith, said to the paralytic, “Son, cheer up! Your sins are forgiven you.” 3Behold, some of the scribes said to themselves, “This man blasphemes.” 4Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said, “Why do you think evil in your hearts? 5For which is easier, to say, ‘Your sins are forgiven;’ or to say, ‘Get up, and walk’? 6But that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins—” (then he said to the paralytic), “Get up, and take up your mat, and go to your house.” 7He arose and departed to his house. 8But when the multitudes saw it, they marveled and glorified God, who had given such authority to men.

1When he entered again into Capernaum after some days, it was heard that he was at home. 2Immediately many were gathered together, so that there was no more room, not even around the door; and he spoke the word to them. 3Four people came, carrying a paralytic to him. 4When they could not come near to him for the crowd, they removed the roof where he was. When they had broken it up, they let down the mat that the paralytic was lying on. 5Jesus, seeing their faith, said to the paralytic, “Son, your sins are forgiven you.” 6But there were some of the scribes sitting there and reasoning in their hearts, 7“Why does this man speak blasphemies like that? Who can forgive sins but God alone?” 8Immediately Jesus, perceiving in his spirit that they so reasoned within themselves, said to them, “Why do you reason these things in your hearts? 9Which is easier, to tell the paralytic, ‘Your sins are forgiven;’ or to say, ‘Arise, and take up your bed, and walk’? 10But that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins”—he said to the paralytic— 11“I tell you, arise, take up your mat, and go to your house.” 12He arose, and immediately took up the mat and went out in front of them all, so that they were all amazed and glorified God, saying, “We never saw anything like this!”

17On one of those days, he was teaching; and there were Pharisees and teachers of the law sitting by who had come out of every village of Galilee, Judea, and Jerusalem. The power of the Lord was with him to heal them. 18Behold, men brought a paralyzed man on a cot, and they sought to bring him in to lay before Jesus. 19Not finding a way to bring him in because of the multitude, they went up to the housetop and let him down through the tiles with his cot into the middle before Jesus. 20Seeing their faith, he said to him, “Man, your sins are forgiven you.” 21The scribes and the Pharisees began to reason, saying, “Who is this who speaks blasphemies? Who can forgive sins, but God alone?” 22But Jesus, perceiving their thoughts, answered them, “Why are you reasoning so in your hearts? 23Which is easier to say, ‘Your sins are forgiven you,’ or to say, ‘Arise and walk’? 24But that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins,” he said to the paralyzed man, “I tell you, arise, take up your cot, and go to your house.” 25Immediately he rose up before them, and took up that which he was laying on, and departed to his house, glorifying God. 26Amazement took hold on all, and they glorified God. They were filled with fear, saying, “We have seen strange things today.”

evidence.head: God and Jesus
evidence.short: Many passages in the New Testament seem to distinguish between "God" and "Jesus", with the former referring to the Father alone.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this suggests Jesus is not God, because if the writers considered him to be divine, they wouldn't have made this distinction.

Proponents argue that the New Testament authors are used to speaking of the Father as "God" and Jesus by name, but because the same authors also display high christology elsewhere, we should understand this "accidental distinction" as an informal expression rather than a statement indicating that Jesus is not God.

bible.summary: 1 Corinthians 8:5–6 ("God" and "Lord" contrast with pagan deities)
bible.text: 5For though there are things that are called “gods”, whether in the heavens or on earth—as there are many “gods” and many “lords”— 6yet to us there is one God, the Father, of whom are all things, and we for him; and one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom are all things, and we live through him.

evidence.head: "My Lord and My God"
evidence.short: St. Thomas, who doubted that it was the resurrected Jesus he was looking at, was convinced when invited to touch his wounds, and he exclaimed, "My lord and my God".
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that, because nobody corrects Thomas, this is a tacit claim by Jesus to being God.

Some critics point out that this statement is not in the vocative case, so it may not be talking about Jesus at all. Rather, St. Thomas could be directing his exclamation *to* God, rather than Jesus.

Proponents generally don't see the use of the nominative here as a problem, because the exclamation doesn't have to be directed *at* Jesus even if it is *about* him.

bible.text: 24But Thomas, one of the twelve, called Didymus, wasn’t with them when Jesus came. 25The other disciples therefore said to him, “We have seen the Lord!” But he said to them, “Unless I see in his hands the print of the nails, put my finger into the print of the nails, and put my hand into his side, I will not believe.” 26After eight days, again his disciples were inside and Thomas was with them. Jesus came, the doors being locked, and stood in the middle, and said, “Peace be to you.” 27Then he said to Thomas, “Reach here your finger, and see my hands. Reach here your hand, and put it into my side. Don’t be unbelieving, but believing.” 28Thomas answered him, “My Lord and my God!” 29Jesus said to him, “Because you have seen me, you have believed. Blessed are those who have not seen and have believed.”

evidence.head: Stephen Prayed to Jesus as Lord
evidence.short: While he was being stoned to death, St. Stephen the Protomartyr prayed, "Lord Jesus, receive my spirit".
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that not only did he pray to Jesus — he called him "Lord" as well. This is a title which is usually used for God in the Septuagint and the New Testament.

Critics argue that it is possible for people in the Second Temple period to use "Lord" as a title more generally, and also to call on people believed to be in Heaven, such as when people wonder if Jesus called out to Elijah in Matthew 27:45–49.
